front.title: Proof of Process Appraisal: Forensic Assessment, Forgery Bounds, and Absence Proofs

abstract.t: This document defines the appraisal procedures for Proof of Process (PoP) evidence. It specifies the forensic assessment mechanisms that evaluate behavioral authenticity, establishes quantified forgery cost bounds, and defines absence proof constructions. The document complements the PoP protocol specification (draft-condrey-rats-pop-protocol) by providing the Verifier-side algorithms and trust evaluation framework.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Proof of Process protocol (draft-condrey-rats-pop-protocol) defines how Attesters collect and seal behavioral evidence during content creation. This companion document specifies how Verifiers appraise that evidence to produce Attestation Results.

The appraisal process encompasses three capabilities: forensic assessment of behavioral authenticity, quantified forgery cost analysis, and absence proof construction for detecting fabricated provenance claims.

section.title: Forensic Assessment
section.t: The forensic assessment evaluates the behavioral characteristics captured in evidence packets against models of human authorship behavior.

section.title: Signal-to-Noise Ratio
section.t: The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) measures the proportion of meaningful editing activity versus noise (random pauses, cursor movements without edits). A human authorship session exhibits characteristic SNR patterns that differ from automated generation.

section.title: Behavioral Entropy
section.t: The Verifier computes Shannon entropy over the timing distributions in each evidence window. Human typing exhibits entropy in the range of 3.0-5.0 bits/sample, while automated input typically shows lower entropy.

section.title: Absence Proofs
section.t: Three types of absence proofs are defined: computationally-bound (VDF timing impossibility), monitoring-dependent (trusted service attestation), and environmental (sensor-based context disproof).

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The appraisal mechanisms inherit the security properties of the underlying protocol. Additional considerations include verifier trust (the Verifier must be trusted not to fabricate Attestation Results) and threshold selection (entropy and SNR thresholds must be calibrated to avoid false positives and negatives).
